etymologies: mid 16th century; earliest use found in William Thomas (d. 1554), scholar, administrator, and alleged traitor. Partly from (i) Italian disciplinante, use as noun of present participle of disciplinare

definitions: A person who scourges himself or herself as a form of religious discipline or penance.

notes.text: Chiefly with reference to Christian religious orders in Spain, Italy, and France.
